Dude easiest answer to this question is to ask people who have almost died. And not the ‘I saw the light and Jesus himself’ and more ‘I am allergic to every food item and am in the er half my life being resurrected’.

Death is your cells attempting to connect to your brain. You can’t use a single muscle cell in your arm to lift a brick, yet when you cut off the blood supply those individual cells suffocate. (You don’t control your automatic breathing but can hold your breath)

Now imagine the roles reversed.

When your cells are sending out automatic chemical or electrical responses at impulses of their own accord for their entire existence when faced with the moment of failure those individual cells panic and flood your system. They’re doing what they know.

If you cut off your finger that individual severed section is still alive right, those cells haven’t died they’re just suffocating and sending out a ton of impulses/chemical back to the brain which it no longer has. But it can be reattached. And when it is properly the cells remember what chemical/electrical impulses mean close/open the hand. As it has twitch responses and responds to electro pads etc. but that moment of open/close is just a fraction of a millisecond of chemical transference from one part of the brain to another and then a few seconds down your arm to your hand (it’s why co-ordination sometimes takes a second and you might not have the cat-like reflexes you think you do)

Point is those cells can’t tell time. And amoeba can’t tell time. So if your brain and cells aren’t on the same page a near death experience may have some time duration issues (it felt like eternity/I didn’t even realize I went down) (think drowning vs aneurism) we say the latter is quicker because there’s no external movement yet we sort of disregard the cells reactions being a real thing and paralysis being natural responses to shock/sudden information.

When given the ultimate info ‘all your cells saying this isn’t working help what’s wrong brain’ sometimes the brain goes for the automatic response of flooding the system over sentences.

The amount of the endogenous Consciousness that the human body is able to metabolize depends on many factors. The less pollutants, poison & other contaminants present in the body will result in the ability to metabolize more of the Consciousness that body is producing. Likewise, the more pollution, contaminants and poison a body has inside of it the less Consciousness it is able to metabolize. This is true for the endogenous Molecules of Consciousness found in humans, as well as any Molecules of Consciousness ingested from external sources.

Here is a list of some of the most common poisons that humans ingest regularly which interferes with a human body metabolizing the Consciousness that it produces, as well as any Consciousness that is ingested from external sources:
alcohol, nicotine, sugar, caffeine, amphetamines, dissociatives, tranquilizers, flouride, and a plethora of other drugs are just some of the substances that interfere with humans metabolizing their own Consciousness, as well as any Molecules of Consciousness ingested from external sources.

You must put more Molecules of Consciousness inside of your physical body in order to attain a Higher level of Consciousness. I believe consciousness is just this: how a human feels about their memories concerning past experiences. A human is made to deeply feel for these memories, because by finding meaning in the past, we can predict the future, and so escape death and achieve reproduction. As all that is going on, a sense of Self is manifested, which makes a human into a person.

I believe there is no meaning to the past, and I believe the future is chaotic and unpredictable. This is a liberating belief, as it eliminates the over-necessity I had for being afraid and for the Self. Without them holding me back, I can live, and experience life, and all of creation.

And at the end of the day, human life is only worth living for, to be around those who feel the same way you feel.

With an open heart, I can experience the other life: the animals and the birds, the bugs and the soil, the trees and plants, the sky and the clouds, the sun and the moon. I can experience me, most of all, as well. And that’s what I, and I alone, am able, and am designed, to do; so, it’s great, whether life is high or is low.

I Have Observed That conditional Existence Is a limit that Inherently and Necessarily Frustrates The Great (As Well As The Ultimate) Motives Of conditionally Manifested beings. Therefore, every individual Must—Through Struggle, and Through The Grace Of Sudden (or, Otherwise, Growing) Insight, or Through The Grace Of Sudden (or, Otherwise, Growing) Faith (or Tacit Certainty)—Learn and Accept A Life-Lesson That Makes ordinary (or worldly) heroes Great and Grants Wisdom To those who Seek The Ultimate.

That Life-Lesson Is This: The Great “Creative” (or Even conventionally idealistic) Goals May Never Be Attained (and They Will Not Be Attained Without A Degree Of heroic Effort, or The Commitment To Struggle and self-Sacrifice)—but The Ultimate Goal (Which Is Happiness Itself) Can Never Be Attained (or Attached To the Apparently Separate self) By Any Means Whatsoever!

The Import Of That Reality Lesson Is This: If You Are Devoted To Great Purposeful Seeking In the conditional worlds, You Will Inevitably Fail If You Avoid Great Struggle and self-Sacrifice, and You May Not Succeed Even If Struggle and self-Sacrifice Are Fully Engaged By You. More Than This, If Your Goal Is The Ultimate (or Happiness Itself, Full and Perfect), You Will Necessarily and Inevitably Fail—Because Happiness Is Not Objectified (or Made Present As a conditional object In the conditional worlds).

Happiness Is An Inherent (or Unconditional and Perfectly Subjective—Rather Than conditional and Objective, or Objectified) Characteristic Of Existence, Reality, or Being (Itself). Therefore, Happiness Cannot Be Found (or Attained) By conditional Seeking.

Even If The Great Searches and The Great Goals Are (Basically) Oriented Toward The Elimination Of the conditions that Apparently Cause Un-Happiness—When Those Great Searches Are Fully Engaged (and Even When Those Great Goals Are Actually Attained), Happiness Itself (Full, True, and Not Threatened) Is Not Attained. Therefore, All The “Glorious” Adventures Of idealistic worldly heroes and All The “Romantic” Attainments Of “Creative” cultural geniuses End In Temporary Elation, Followed (Inevitably) By Disillusionment—and Then (At Best), Unless There Is No “Recovery” From Inevitable Disillusionment, There May Be A Reawakening Of The Stressful Motive To Seek and Attain Once More. (And Such Seeking and “Attaining” Will Tend To Continue—Until Disillusionment Itself Becomes Acceptance Of The Great Life-Lesson That Undermines All Seeking.)

Conventionally heroic and “Creative” personalities Tend To Grasp Only A Portion Of The Great Lesson Of conditional Existence. They Realize a genius For Struggle and self-Sacrifice, but (Unless—By Grace, and By self-Transcendence, Even By Advancing To The Ultimate Stages Of Life—they Realize The Truth Itself) they Never Realize Happiness Itself.

Consciousness is at the core of many of our decision making processes, it's not just an accessory feature.  The simplest solution is, unfortunately, not very interesting. The whole reason for the full brain is that it gives us infinite possibilities, therefore, removing half the brain does not mean the other half will account for the missing half, but merely compensates for it.

The missing half has its own capacity and function, so to remove it compromises the integrity of the whole brain functionality.

Now, that's not to say if a child is born with half a brain (which they have been known to) that they cannot acquire full capacity and necessary brain functionality in order to live 'normal,' this can in fact happen, because the brain can rewire and learn the components necesssry to help with fundamental neurological operation. But to take away a part of the brain that has already formed its neurological pathways, simply because there is a blip in the system so to speak (seizures) is completely and undeniably foolish.

Epigenetics is a fundamental principle of biology that proves that in the right environment, cells within our whole body can be healed ("The biology of belief'' - Bruce Lipton) and it shows how natural interference can greatly impact the complex structures of our cells and help us to overcome any degerative diseases etc...

I believe the' removal of the brain is nefarious, and we are so brainwashed (pun intended) into believing it is the only way to 'heal' / 'fix' / 'cure' different ailments, as opposed to us being able to heal ourselves accordingly.

When we have a cut, we heal automatically, but we take it for granted and do not appreciate the complex internal fundamental mechanics inside the body that go to ensuring that wound heals itself.... We don't go chopping our fingers and arms off everytime we have bruise or a cut do we!!

I think we are more advanced than we want to believe, and taking parts of people's brains is more about 'medical' curiosity and experiment, than it is about medical necessity!!

First do no harm..... Half the time these medical institutions spew a rhetoric that they know we will accept because they appear credible and legit, but seriously we need to move away from medical procedures as draconian and antiquated as this, and lead with not only science but the super biologically intricate capacity of the human body to be able to heal itself... I am a physicist and I will provide solid arguments that prove that consciousness cannot be generated by the brain (in my youtube channel you can find a video with more detailed explanations). Many argue that consciousness is an emergent property of the brain, but it is possible to show that such hypothesis is inconsistent with our scientific knowledges. In fact, it is possible to show that all the examples of emergent properties consists of concepts used to describe how an external object appear to our conscious mind, and not how it is in itself, which means how the object is independently from our observation. In other words, emergent properties are ideas conceived to describe or classify, according to arbitrary criteria and from an arbitrary point of view, certain processes or systems. In summary, emergent properties are intrinsically subjective, since they are based on the arbitrary choice to focus on certain aspects of a system and neglet other aspects, such as microscopic structures and processes; emergent properties consist of ideas through which we describe how the external reality appears to our conscious mind: without a conscious mind, these ideas (= emergent properties) would not exist at all.

Here comes my first argument: arbitrariness, subjectivity, classifications and approximate descriptions, imply the existence of a conscious mind, which can arbitrarily choose a specific point of view and focus on certain aspects while neglecting others. It is obvious that consciousness cannot be considered an emergent property of the physical reality, because consciousenss is a preliminary necessary condition for the existence of any emergent property. We have then a logical contradiction. Nothing which presupposes the existence of consciousness can be used to try to explain the existence of consciousness.

Here comes my second argument: our scientific knowledge shows that brain processes consist of sequences of ordinary elementary physical processes; since consciousness is not a property of ordinary elementary physical processes, then a succession of such processes cannot have cosciousness as a property. In fact we can break down the process and analyze it step by step, and in every step consciousness would be absent, so there would never be any consciousness during the entire sequence of elementary processes. It must be also understood that considering a group of elementary processes together as a whole is an arbitrary choice. In fact, according to the laws of physics, any number of elementary processes is totally equivalent. We could consider a group of one hundred elementary processes or ten thousand elementary processes, or any other number; this choice is arbitrary and not reducible to the laws of physics. However, consciousness is a necessary preliminary condition for the existence of arbitrary choices; therefore consciousness cannot be a property of a sequence of elementary processes as a whole, because such sequence as a whole is only an arbitrary and abstract concept that cannot exist independently of a conscious mind.

Here comes my third argument: It should also be considered that brain processes consist of billions of sequences of elementary processes that take place in different points of the brain; if we attributed to these processes the property of consciousness, we would have to associate with the brain billions of different consciousnesses, that is billions of minds and personalities, each with its own self-awareness and will; this contradicts our direct experience, that is, our awareness of being a single person who is able to control the voluntary movements of his own body with his own will. If cerebral processes are analyzed taking into account the laws of physics, these processes do not identify any unity; this missing unit is the necessarily non-physical element (precisely because it is missing in the brain), the element that interprets the brain processes and generates a unitary conscious state, that is the human mind.

Here comes my forth argument: Consciousness is characterized by the fact that self-awareness is an immediate intuition that cannot be broken down or fragmented into simpler elements. This characteristic of consciousness of presenting itself as a unitary and non-decomposable state, not fragmented into billions of personalities, does not correspond to the quantum description of brain processes, which instead consist of billions of sequences of elementary incoherent quantum processes. When someone claims that consciousness is a property of the brain, they are implicitly considering the brain as a whole, an entity with its own specific properties, other than the properties of the components. From the physical point of view, the brain is not a whole, because its quantum state is not a coherent state, as in the case of entangled systems; the very fact of speaking of "brain" rather than many cells that have different quantum states, is an arbitrary choice. This is an important aspect, because, as I have said, consciousness is a necessary preliminary condition for the existence of arbitrariness. So, if a system can be considered decomposable and considering it as a whole is an arbitrary choice, then it is inconsistent to assume that such a system can have or generate consciousness, since consciousness is a necessary precondition for the existence of any arbitrary choice. In other words, to regard consciousness as a property ofthe brain, we must first define what the brain is, and to do so we must rely only on the laws of physics, without introducing arbitrary notions extraneous to them; if this cannot be done, then it means that every property we attribute to the brain is not reducible to the laws of physics, and therefore such property would be nonphysical. Since the interactions between the quantum particles that make up the brain are ordinary interactions, it is not actually possible to define the brain based solely on the laws of physics. The only way to define the brain is to arbitrarily establish that a certain number of particles belong to it and others do not belong to it, but such arbitrariness is not admissible. In fact, the brain is not physically separated from the other organs of the body, with which it interacts, nor is it physically isolated from the external environment, just as it is not isolated from other brains, since we can communicate with other people, and to do so we use physical means, for example acoustic waves or electromagnetic waves (light). This necessary arbitrariness in defining what the brain is, is sufficient to demonstrate that consciousness is not reducible to the laws of physics. Besides, since the brain is an arbitrary concept, and consciousness is the necessary preliminary condition for the existence of arbitrariness, consciousness cannot be a property of the brain.
Based on these considerations, we can exclude that consciousness is generated by brain processes or is an emergent property of the brain. Marco Biagini

It's becoming clearer that with all the brain and consciousness theories out there, the proof will be in the pudding. By this I mean, can any particular theory be used to create a human adult level conscious machine. My bet is on the late Gerald Edelman's Extended Theory of Neuronal Group Selection. The lead group in robotics based on this theory is the Neurorobotics Lab at UC at Irvine. Dr. Edelman distinguished between primary consciousness, which came first in evolution, and that humans share with other conscious animals, and higher order consciousness, which came to only humans with the acquisition of language. A machine with primary consciousness will probably have to come first.

The thing I find special about the TNGS is the Darwin series of automata created at the Neurosciences Institute by Dr. Edelman and his colleagues in the 1990's and 2000's. These machines perform in the real world, not in a restricted simulated world, and display convincing physical behavior indicative of higher psychological functions necessary for consciousness, such as perceptual categorization, memory, and learning. They are based on realistic models of the parts of the biological brain that the theory claims subserve these functions. The extended TNGS allows for the emergence of consciousness based only on further evolutionary development of the brain areas responsible for these functions, in a parsimonious way. No other research I've encountered is anywhere near as convincing.

Consciousness is nothing more than the processing of sensory information by a biological entity that senses the limits of its boundaries. The more sensory information that the entity is capable of simultaneously receive and process, the higher the level of consciousness it possesses. The cell possesses the lowest level of consciousness, humans have the highest level because of their brain capacity to process and store information. Artificial intelligence will have consciousness once it meets all requirements. The universe does not meet these requirements so there is not a conscious universe (sorry Deepak Chopra). Consciousness does not survive after the end of the entity because consciousness is an attribute of the entity. Give me my Nobel Prize!

Example: We know what became of this world's version of Adolf Hitler. But who would he have become if The Academy of Fine Arts in Vienna had accepted him as a student? As to your "Cells from me and from you" question goes. Whatever the result, if the two guinea pigs survived the process, neither would be the same, anymore than the transplant would! I would not be you, and you would not be me. The BASE would always be there, your whiteboard and mine, but we are each uniquely put together. Change the way the pieces fit together, and neither you, nor I, would ... or could, ever be the same! Gene Roddenberry created a question when he fictionally created his "transporter". The transporters disintegrate a traveler's physical form and transports the particles to a target destination, where they are reintegrated into something similar to what you're talking about ... a carbon copy using the same parts, albeit slightly altered by the process. For the sake of the show, everyone was the same upon arriving at their destination, but would that really be the case? How robust is the human dichotomy of mind and body? The question you should be asking is: "What is infinity? And how closely does it's every part and parcel mirror the First Law of Thermodynamics ... "Energy can neither be created nor destroyed, only changed"? Can anything really be destroyed if it's an aspect of infinity. And if it can't, then what is your consciousness experiment revealing?

I prefer the word "awareness" over "consciousness" in this context, because "consciousness" has at least two meanings. It can mean "awareness," as Michael discusses here, or "wakefulness," meaning one isn't asleep, in a coma, etc. The word "consciousness" gets muddy when you consider dreaming. I'm definitely aware when I'm dreaming, but I'm not conscious in the sense of being awake. I've gotten picky about this issue because I've encountered headlines like, "Scientists Find the Seat of Consciousness," but when you read the articles, you find that they're really talking about the structures in the brain and the neurological processes that keep us awake. As Michael said, we don't yet know what awareness is, and it's possible that we never will.

All that I know at the moment, consciousness doesn't reside in the brain, which I consider just a sort of interface that makes the body work in relation with the mind. And mind is a virtual thing too, its functions is to create the illusion of the ego, which is necessary to live as individual beings. Appearently the purpose of this universe is experiencing life from as many points of view as possible, maybe infinite).
I think that mind belongs to the soul, which is still another kind of body since it's still and individual thing, even if it lives on a more subtle plane of existence, so to speak. Soul also contains the ego, which is the result of what the indian philosophy call karma, made of all the imprinted experiences, actions and emotions that every soul accumulates from life to life. All these things make up the ego and so the illusion of identity and also determine the kind of body/life/experiences you're going to have in each life; and the more the ego grows, the more one identifies themself with the body, which happen to be the only source of conscious experience in the current life.
Those who reach "enlightenment" just find the way to bypass this "algorithm", to reduce their ego (dissolving their karma) at the point they no more identify themselves with their body and mind, understanding what's the true nature of life and how our (uncontrolled) mind is the only responsible for any suffering.

One can stop here and be ok with the fact that we're eternal beings with an individual conscience that survives the death of the body, but if we want to reach the very top of the pyramid, what we are beyond all of this, is pure consciousness, eternal and impersonal. I think enlighted people experience only a glimpse of this state, since they still live in a limited body and mind. There's no god creating the universe, we do it right now (since time and space are virtual aswell as the universe) on the highest level of existence, which is also the only reality to effectively exist... even if the idea of existence is dual since it implies non-existence, but duality is something that only belongs to this virtual universe then... we can say that we exist but we also don't :P

I get the feeling that the fact consciousness clings to complex intelligent life is of vital importance in understanding it's behaviour. Life began from things very small, and initially very simple, but gradually the patterns in nature due to physical laws began to push a very small snowball called complexity, complexity started out mixing atoms and compounds in a universal soup of matter and energy, sometimes there was enough energy and matter to make a chemical reaction happen and out pops a new molecule, a potential ingredient for life, and with the growth of complexity, consciousness also grew, now using elaborate systems of proteins and solutions and ions, building neural networks to store and sort information, firmly embedding its roots into soil of the universe. We are likely a brief glimpse in the development of consciousness as it climbs the ladder of complexity, the next rung up? we can't know. For a long time, complexity grew at a snails pace, because consciousness couldn't get proper traction, but more recently, consciousness has collected enough information to understand scientific method and how to apply it, who knows how far that path leads. No doubt one day consciousness will perpetuate itself throughout the cosmos, growing into something far wiser and more conscientious than ourselves. As the upper echelon of consciousness surpasses our own, it might cast an eye, on the small evolutionary steps along the way, that in time taught it how to thrive in a universe which it long knew nothing about, that reminded it of what it was like to be a very small thing, in a very big universe, a time when even the sense of self was perhaps a foreign concept. Hopefully when consciousness controls the universe, there can still be a place for the human being and we can live in a utopia with all of consciousness' creations, and if not, c'est la vie.

I will keep things rather simplified in order to not require a book to explain the subject matter talked about in this video. (Though this will be lengthy regardless)
In terms of the Hemispherectomy, the anatomy of the brain needs to be taken into consideration. The brain has more than just the 2 hemispheres to its structure. It also has the midbrain, which is what the two hemispherical structures are connected to, or more accurately, grow from. Removing one of these halves would not include any of the midbrain structures, and hence would not be able to carry out function independently, since its connection to the rest of the body would be severed, as the midbrain is where the neural communication from the body (save for the cranial nerves) is transferred to and from the many structures of the brain. If the midbrain is damaged in any way, your chances of survival are essentially 0%.
If this new half was transplanted into a new host body successfully somehow, it would still need to be reconnected to a new midbrain structure system, which really calls the shots on how it behaves. The interesting thing would be that, if the new implanted brain contained formed memories that were entirely localized to that hemisphere, the memories would likely be transferred along with it.
The main trouble with this is that DNA is extremely specific, and if cells containing DNA that don't pertain to the host's DNA are suddenly implanted, those cells will get targeted by the immune system of the new host and marked for destruction. Some cells are transfusion/transplant capable thanks to an understanding of how cells are identified and communicate in the body. With that being said, even if this other half of your brain was successfully transplanted into another host, the brain that would continue to be "you" would be the half that is still connected to your original midbrain, and the transplanted brain would, over time, be converted to being accessory to the new host.
This is all assuming that we don't take into account the many, many things that would make this particularly impossible.
Another thing I would like to touch upon is that each separate hemisphere tends to exhibit its own preferences when communication between the two hemispheres, which is done through a structure called the corpus callosum, has been severed. Subtle differences such as color preference have been observed in such subjects. (On a side note, this may explain why we "talk to ourselves", and be a contributing factor to indecisiveness)

In terms of the "swampman", even if the atoms had reassembled perfectly to replicate you after the original was destroyed, the newly created person wouldn't have any of the memories that the original person had, and they would essentially be "born again", with a blank slate for a brain that would have to relearn everything that the original you learned while growing and developing, including muscular control and speech. The newly atomically assembled person, even if being a perfect clone, would still be a new person and not you, because your experiences in life have a large determining factor on who you are. They would likely develop similar interests and (objectively) personality, but still not be you.

In terms of the swapping cells one by one thing, it comes down to the previous issues stated before. depending on the speed of the transfer, the new cells would either be targeted and destroyed if they were incompatible, or simply accepted as new cells like in a transfusion or transplant if they were compatible. Once the brain is disassembled, that's pretty much it. That's the end of the person as they were known. This is because the brain would have to relearn and recreate neurological pathways in order to regain function.

What I find is a more curious question is; At what point is the thing that determines whether you exist to observe through your eyes or anyone else's eyes determined? Why, out of all life, is the host you occupy, your host?

It may be said that if there was no life, existence would not be existence; it would be no different from non-existence. Life is the light of the spirit, and consciousness is the light of life. Since life and consciousness are important to this great extent; and since there is self-evidently an absolutely perfect order in the universe, and a masterly precision and most wise harmony; and since our lowly, wretched globe, our wandering earth has been filled with uncountable numbers of animate beings, intelligent beings, and beings with spirits; it may be concluded with decisive certainty that those heavenly palaces, those lofty constellations also have animate and conscious inhabitants appropriate to them. As fish swim in water, so are those luminous inhabitants present in the fire of the sun. Fire does not consume light; indeed, Fire aids light.
Moreover, since, as is plain to see, pre-eternal power creates innumerable animate beings and beings with spirits from the most common substances and densest matter, and giving it great importance, transmutes dense matter by means of life into a subtle substance; and since it strews the light of life everywhere in great abundance, and gilds most things with the light of consciousness; with such flawless power and faultless wisdom, the All-Wise and All-Powerful One would certainly not neglect the other floods of subtle matter like light and ether, which are close to and fitting for the spirit; He would not leave them without life, without consciousness, inanimate. Indeed, He creates animate and conscious beings in great numbers from light, which is also matter, and even from meanings, air, and even words. Just as He creates numerous different species of animals, so from these torrents of subtle matter He creates numerous different spirit creatures. One kind of them are the angels, others are the varieties of spirit beings and jinn. If you wish to see just how true, self-evident, and rational it is to accept the existence of great numbers of angels and spirit beings, and as the Qur'an shows, just how contrary to truth and wisdom, and what a superstition, aberration, delirium and foolishness it is not to accept them, consider the following comparison.
There were two men, one rustic and uncouth, the other civilized and intelligent, who made friends and went to a splendid city like Istanbul. In a distant corner of that civilized and magnificent city they came across a dirty, wretched little building, a factory. They looked and saw that the strange factory was full of miserable, impoverished men working. All around the building were beings with spirits and animate beings, but their means of livelihood and conditions of life were such that some were herbivorous, they lived only on plants, while others were piscivorous, they ate nothing but fish.
The two men watched the scene. Then they saw in the distance thousands of adorned palaces and lofty castles. Among the palaces were spacious workshops and broad squares. Because of either the distance, or the defectiveness of the men's eyesight, or because they had hidden themselves, the inhabitants of the palaces were not visible to the two men. Twenty-Fourth Window
* Death is a proof of dominicality as much as life is a proof of it; it is a most powerful proof of Divine unity. As the verse,
Who creates death and life {[*]: Qur'an, 67:2.}
indicates, death is not non-existence, annihilation, non-being, an authorless extinction; rather, as is shown in the First Letter, it is a being discharged from service by an All-Wise Author, a change of residence, an exchange of bodies, a rest from duty, a being freed from the prison of the body; it is a wise and orderly work of wisdom. Indeed, just as the living face of the earth and the well-fashioned and living creatures upon it testify to the necessary existence and unity of an All-Wise Maker, so too with their deaths do those living beings bear witness to the eternity and unity of an Ever-Living and Self-Subsistent One. Since it is proved and elucidated in the Twenty-Second Word that death is an extremely powerful proof of Divine unity and eternity, we refer the discussion to that Word and here only explain one important point. It is as follows:
Both with their existences do living beings point to the existence of a Necessarily Existent One, and with their deaths do those living beings testify to the eternity and unity of an Ever-Living Eternal One. For example, the face of the earth, which is a single living creature, points to its Maker with its order and circumstances; so too it points to Him when it dies. That is, when winter conceals the earth's face with its white shroud, it turns the gazes of men away from itself their gaze moves to the past behind the corpse of that departing spring and it shows them a far wider scene. That is to say, all the past springs of the earth, which were all miracles of power, inform them that new living springtime creatures of the earth will come, and since they all testify to the existence of those future wonders of Divine power, each a living earth, they testify brilliantly and powerfully and on a vast scale to the necessary existence, unity, everlastingness, and eternity of an All-Glorious Maker, an All-Powerful One of Perfection, an Ever-Living Eternal One; they demonstrate such brilliant proofs that whether one wants to or not they make one declare: "I believe in God, the One, the Unique!" In Short: According to the meaning of the verse,
And gives life to the earth after its death, {[*]: Qur'an, 30:19.}
just as this living earth testifies to the Maker with the spring, so with its death it turns man's gaze to the miracles of Divine power lined up on the two wings of time, the past and the future; it alludes to thousands of miracles of power in place of one miracle. And each of those springs testifies more certainly than this present spring, for those which have departed towards the past have gone together with their apparent causes, and after them others like them have come in their places. This means that apparent causes are nothing: only that an All-Powerful One of Glory creates the springs, and tying them to causes shows that He has sent them. As for the faces of the earth lined up in future time, they testify still more brilliantly. For they will be made anew from nothing, from non-being, and sent; they will be put on the earth, made to do their duty, and then sent away.
And so, O heedless one deviated into nature and drowning in its swamp! How can something which does not possess hands wise and powerful enough to reach all the past and all the future interfere in the life of the earth? Can your total nonentity of nature interfere in it? If you want to be saved, say: "At the very most, nature is a notebook of Divine power. And as for chance, it is a veil to hidden Divine wisdom which conceals our ignorance." Approach the truth!
.....
O wretched worshipper of causes! With what can you explain these important truths? How can you deceive yourself? If you have sense, rend the veil of causes and declare: "He is One, He has no partners!" Be saved from innumerable delusions!

And among His signs is the creation of the heavens and the earth and the variations in your tongues and in your colours; verily in that are signs for those who know. {[*]: Qur'an, 30:22.}
We look at the universe, and we see that a wisdom and ordering embrace everything from the cells of the body to the totality of the world.
We look at the cells of the body, and we see that through the command and according to the law of one who considers what is beneficial for the body and administers it, there is a significant management in those miniscule cells. One the one hand a sort of sustenance is stored up in the stomach in the form of fat and expended at the time of need, and on the other in those tiny cells there is a regulation and storing up.
We look at plants, and a most wise planning and nurturing are apparent.
We look at animals, and we see a rearing and nurturing which are generous to the utmost degree.
We look at the mighty elements of the universe, and we see a majestic government and illumination following momentous aims.
We look at the universe as a whole, and we see a perfect ordering for exalted instances of wisdom and elevated aims, as though it was a country, a city, or a palace.
As is described and proved in the First Stopping-Place of the Thirty-Second Word, from minute particles to the stars, not the tiniest place is left for associating partners with God. All beings are in effect so interrelated that one who cannot subjugate all the stars and hold them in his hand, cannot make a particle heed his claims to be its lord and sustainer. It is necessary to own all the stars in order to be the true sustainer of a single particle.
Furthermore, as is described and proved in the Second Stopping-Place of the Thirty-Second Word, one not capable of creating and arranging the heavens cannot make the individual features on the human face. That is to say, one who is not Sustainer of all the heavens cannot make the distinguishing features on a single human face.
Thus, this is a window as large as the universe, which, if looked through, the following verses will also appear to the mind's eye, written on the pages of the universe in large letters:
God is the Creator of all things, and of all things He is the Guardian and Disposer * His are the keys of the heavens and the earth. {[*]: Qur'an, 39:62-3.}
One who does not see these has either no mind or no heart. Or he is an animal in human form!
*There is no God but He, everything will perish save His countenance, His is the command and to Him shall you return. {[*]: Qur'an, 28:88.}

This video is based on the assumption that Consciousness is directly correlated to the brain or is situated in the brain. That's why the question of brain transplant seems very confusing. You should first clarify that you are making that assumption, and if possible why you are making that assumption, otherwise it seems arbitrary.

To understand consciousness one should take time to understand what one truly is. This might help, here is some food for thought. To understand God one should first understand the nature of knowledge. Knowledge inherently has no material form. That which we see is the physical representation of knowledge. For instance, imagine all light bulbs on earth are destroyed, even then the knowledge of the light bulb still exists. Since knowledge inherently has no material form it is eternal (no beginning & no end) Now with that said one needs to understand the different types of knowledge. 1st of course is the knowledge of awareness. We know that it exists because it is what we truly are. We are the knowledge of awareness & since we know that knowledge inherently has no material form, we know that what we truly are is eternal in nature. (no beginning & no end). Our bodies are the physical representation of the knowledge of all it's corresponding parts both big & small. If the knowledge of a thing didn't exist then we would never see the physical representation of it. Now if we know that we are eternal in  nature, then we know that some other being did not create us, or even create the knowledge of the light bulb, since it too is inherently eternal (no beginning & no end). However, that is not to say there isn't an intelligence of awareness that has been awakened unto the knowledge of all things. (Effectively making them GOD). One could argue that there is truly only this One knowledge of awareness (GOD) in existence and it is focusing it's awareness in every variation of perceived reality simultaneously. Which effectively makes us all apart of a single whole. For instance imagine you where seeing reality through 2 different bodies at the same time and in one of the bodies you had blocked out your perception of humility & in the other body you blocked out your perception of logical thinking. Now it would still be you perceiving reality through both bodies but individually they would be perceptually separate. On the other hand one could argue that since one piece of knowledge is eternally separate from any other piece of knowledge, like the knowledge of the light bulb is eternally separate from the knowledge of a strawberry. One could argue there is a single unique piece of knowledge (That is you) combined with the knowledge of awareness effectively setting you apart from all others. Eternal none the less.

No, but seriously. Why is there something instead of nothing?

Last night, as I was creeping around the internet at 2:43am while the adults of the world slept, my eyes glanced by the headline, “Why is there something instead of nothing?” on the sidebar of a site I was on. I didn’t click the article.

I finally went to bed, planning to sleep eight hours, when at 7am I decide that actually, it was a better plan to wake up and stare at the ceiling for three hours thinking about why there was something. Instead of nothing.

I had heard the question before. It’s an old one that lots of people have pondered. But until 7am today, it hadn’t fully hit me how unbelievably boggling a question it was. It’s not a question—it’s the question—and the more you think about it, the less sense it makes.

First, my mind goes to “Wait—why is there anything at all?” Why is there space and time and matter and energy at all?

Then, I think about the alternative. What if there were just…nothing…at all…ever…anywhere? What if nothing ever was in the first place? But what? No. That can’t—there has to be something.

Nothing is truly a crazy concept. I’d keep thinking about a false nothing—like a vast empty vacuum (which is something) or nothing here, but other universes elsewhere in other dimensions (which is something), or nothing now, but at some point, way before or after now, there being something (which is something). Even in my question in the paragraph above, I refer to “ever” and “anywhere”—two words that themselves only exist in the world of something, because time and space are something.

Trying to wrap my head around true, utter nothing, is what kept my eyes extra wide as I stared at the ceiling between 7am and 10am this morning.

But the fact is, there isn’t nothing—there’s something. We’re something. The Earth is something. Space is something. Time is something. The observable universe and its 100 billion galaxies are something.

Which then leads me to, Why? Why does all this something exist? And where the hell are we? If this universe is the only thing there is, that’s kind of weird and illogical—why would this big space just exist by itself in an otherwise nothing situation? More logical, to me, is the bubbling, frothing multiverse situation—but okay, we still then have the same problem. Why is this bubbling thing happening? Where is it happening? In what context is it happening?

That’s our main issue—we have no context. It’s like being zoomed in on a single letter and not knowing anything else—is the letter part of a book? In a library somewhere? Is it part of a word that exists by itself? Is it a single letter all alone? Is it part of some code we don’t understand? We have no fucking idea, because all we can see is this one letter. We have no idea about the context.

Religious people have a quick answer to “Why is there something instead of nothing?” I’m not religious, but when I’ve thought hard enough about it, I’ve realized that it’s as plausible as anything else that life on Earth was created by some other intelligent life, or that we’re part of a simulation, or a bunch of other possibilities that would all entail us having a creator. But in each possible case, the existence of the creator still needs an explanation—why was there an original creator instead of nothing—and to me, any religious explanation inevitably hits the same wall.

I did a little reading this morning to see how people who had thought about this a lot more than I had felt about the question. Not surprisingly, no one has a clue.

Certain scientists believe that quantum mechanics suggests that nothing is inherently “unstable,” that it’s possible for little bubbles of space-time (something) to form spontaneously (out of nothing), and that if a thing is not forbidden by the laws of quantum physics, it is guaranteed to happen.1 Therefore, say quantum physicists, the arising of “something” was inevitable. I’ll file this whole paragraph in the Whatever the Fuck That Means cabinet.

Others, like Joel Achenbach, believe that there’s no such thing as nothing in the first place. He explains:

Seems to me that “nothing,” for all its simplicity and symmetry and lack of arbitrariness, is nonetheless an entirely imaginary state, or condition, and we can say with confidence that it has never existed. “Nothing” is dreamed up in the world of something, in the brains of philosophers etc. on a little blue planet orbiting an ordinary yellow star in a certain spiral galaxy.

I don’t quite get Achenbach’s logic. Why does there have to be a physical world at all? Why is a physical world an automatic thing? But then…if there weren’t a physical world—ever—then what, there’s just fucking nothing at all?

This is ruining me.

In German, the terminology is very interesting. Consciousness means "Bewusstsein" which is made up of "bewusst" and "sein". "sein" just means "to be" and "bewusst", which comes from "Wissen" or "knowledge", basically translates to "to be aware". So "Bewusstsein" would basically translate to "to be aware of being". Then there also is "Selbstbewusstsein" which is usually used as "confidence", and since "selbst" means "self", it translates to "to be aware of being oneself" which just blows my mind every time I think of confidence.

Your problem is the presumption you start with; the unspoken and unquestioned assumption you base everything you say here on. You think that “you” are the body. You equate the body with your sense of self, even though this sense of self has not changed your whole life, while the body/thoughts/personality have. This is a fundamental error that causes all these bizarre questions—like “What if every cell was swapped in two bodies.” The answer is that you are just mixing up cells, not selfs. Because the sense of self, or I, is the same for all bodies, so it is never swapped. Being the same for both, it can’t be. (This is the “One” or the “Oneness” that people have heard of and seek with awakenings/enlightenment/Self-Realization.) It’s likely though, in such a swap, that the memories—which make the illusion that we are different and separate—would not survive this swap, and so you’d have two new “people,” with blank slates; no memory and no history. However, still nothing would happen to the sense of self for either of them. It remained as it always has been—eternal, unchanging, and indestructible.

Well my question is how does this affect their ability to move their head? If you think about it, the brain usually fits the skull, any gaps in the skull should result in the pressure to move matter to the empty space. Basically if you put a ping pong ball inside of a tennis ball, the ping pong ball can move around, and that's very bad for a ping pong ball that's made of highly delicate neurons and microscopic brain structures.

But if you have a bunch of sealant, which fills the gap between the inside of the tennis ball, such as the brain has its own cerebral spinal fluid among other things. It acts to secure this matter in place. Reducing, but not eliminating damage from inertial force.

This is why you can lose consciousness from just moving the brain in a weird way, not necessarily by smacking the skull. Also another fun thing to maybe not try - spinning in a spinny chair. Do it really fast, then stop. And now you know exactly what vertigo is. Your brain does too.

One of my YT accounts, made when YT first started, has a few thousand subscribers even though I never produced any content. People have asked me why so many subbed to me, and I told them that in the beginning, people subbed to one another because of their playlists. If you had a specific thing you liked and you found other people with similar tastes, it helped connect you with videos you might not otherwise discover. Back in the early days of YT there weren't a lot of content creators with a specific goal, so much as just a bunch of people who uploaded videos. So playlists helped organize YT content a lot, especially if you were looking for something very specific. Once youtube was more organized and people devoted channels specifically for certain topics or focus, the need for playlists seemed to become somewhat secondary, and I don't think a lot of people nowadays understand how important playlists used to be for organizing information.

This is my theory if you go as Vsauce goes :
To me, consciousness is that your brain retained memories at a certain moment and at a certain point that can make a "story" : the story of your life.
If you'd put half of your brain into another body and the other half in another body, your "consciousness" would "die", for two major reasons :

- First, like I said, consciousness is a gallery of memories that your brain has stored, just like a book. And memories are what you have seen or felt during your life. But what do you see every day that makes memories ? Your body ! And so, if your brain changed its body, your brain wouldn't "recognize" itself because your body is a part of your memories, your "story", and if you take that piece away, your story is incomplete. A computer cannot be accessed whiteout a complete password, so your brain wou wouldn't think that you're "yourself" and wouldn't let the memories go.
A good example would be a person that had a big accident, and then had his head damaged enough to go blank, lose his memories. Then imagine the person was hospitalised for several months, maybe even a year. Then he wakes up ! He would never remember his identity until it is reexplained to him or shown to him. It is the plot point of metsl gear solid 5 after all, and so, not impossible.

- The second option then would be going from the first option, trying to find a solution. If I was a scientist, and I knew that the brain wouldn't "remember" itself because of the new body, I'd try to make a "perfect" copy (you could take triplets or clone the body, but the second one is unlikely). Then what would happen ? I'll first go with the clone otion, as of being the most impossible.
You make a clone with no brain, then insert the brain in the body. I have a pretty neat idea of what would happen. If by chance, the body can process to have a new brain without killing it, then the "body" with all his senses, would remember its memories. But now we have the big problem. Your brain could quickly induce that you are in a new body. But how ? Because of the memories this time. "But didn't you say that the brain wouldn't unlock ?". Yes, but the brain would be tricked at first to believe that the cloned body is your real body. Then they would be a surge of information unlocking in the entire body ! And by there, we have two routes : either the brain is smart enough to know it is not normal to get as much info in so little time, and then he would consider itself it's own entity or either that the info would be canalized slowly enough to not have the previous thought. Now, the brain will recognize or know something. Maybe it would be that some of your scars and bad reflexes have disappeared or that your brainknows it has a new body because you had ordered it to beforehand (because you remembered it).
And now it is more a philosophical question : will the old brain with the new body consider itself to be you or will it go on on its "new" story. But in either case your consciousness "dies".
Unless you use manipulation, like in MGS5. Lol.
Also the triplet option is more or less the same, just more possible and easier, even more at yonger age, were memories aren't developed yet.
Also also, this is a theory and I'm not a expert about the subject, so what I say is not to be taken as a 100% truth, I'mjust giving a opinion. And good video Vsauce.

The brain is an area of neurophysiology activity. Neurophysiology activity consists of electrochemical reaction. Thus at any given time, the brain state is defined by a subset of electrochemical reactions, derived from a large set of possible reactions. Consider the phenomenon of a. conscious thought. As at any given time the brain physical state consists of a collection of electrochemical reactions (events), it can be inferred that they are collectively responsible for the conscious thought. This means that at least in part, simultaneous events are responsible for thought. In other words, thought creates a connection between simultaneous events. This is in contradiction to the consequences of special relativity, which states that the fastest connection between events is the speed of light and thus excludes the possibility of connection between simultaneous events. Consider the memorizing of, say, the value 5. This would necessarily involve more than 1 point in space as, say, if it is assumed a single electron records 5 by taking a particular potential. Then it by itself cannot define (or know) 5, as its magnitude would be defined only with respect to another datum or event defined as a unit potential, thus involving at least 2 simultaneous events. Consider the experience of vision. While we focus our attention on an object of vision, we are still aware of a background and, thus, a whole collection of events. This would mean at least an equal collection of physical events in the brain are involved.
Take the experience of listening to music. It would mean being aware of what went before. Like vision, it would probably mean that while our attention at any given time is focused at that point in time, it is aware of what went before and what is to follow. In other words, it spans the time axis. Many great composers have stated that they are able to hear their whole composition. Thus their acoustic experience is probably like the average person's visual experience. While focusing at a particular point in time of their composition, they are nevertheless aware of what went before and what is to come. The rest of the composition is like the background of a visual experience. Experiencing the composition in this way, they are able to traverse it in a similar fashion to which a painting is observed. In this sense, an average person in comparison can be seen as having tunnel hearing (like tunnel vision) when it comes to music, thus making it very difficult for him or her to reproduce or create new music. It can be seen that consciousness is a 4-D phenomenon. If it is a physically explainable phenomenon, such an explanation would involve EPR type effects and as such physical explanations at a quantum level will be involved.

I think you are confusing the "ego" with the witness of the ego. You defined consciousness, and therefore, whatever science may find, is not necessarily the answer to what we experience, but an answer to the definition.

We humans are so arrogant to think that only we are conscious. For that thunderbolt question, answer this: Is the fusion in the sun different than the fusion of other stars?

You said: "Focus on yourself". That is a great exercise. But who's focusing and knowing? And do we really die? What if in the future same "structure" occurred? That structure will have different memories. Either one has to say we are nothing but experience and memory and yes we die, or one has to agree that if same structure occurs, then we are here again, yet with different ego. How do you know people in coma or deep sleep are not conscious? There is something in us (some also call it consciousness) which is simply the presence, without memory. If you had no capacity for memory, will you be conscious? That will depend on the definition, but is it a requirement for consciousness to be aware of itself? In my definition, it is not requirement. Just seeing a color or hearing a sound, even not knowing what that is or remembering, still is consciousness, although useless for humans.

The answer to these questions is really really simple to comprehend, but perhaps not quantifiable as "science" and "quakadamics" require. Look at life itself. Humans understood a concept of life since ancient time. Then scientists defined life in biology. All was great until scientists told us that the life which they defined is the life humans understood since ancient times.

Look at any color. They tell you color is only in your mind. In that case, everything is only in your mind. Also, without that color, or any similar thing (such as sound) which is only in your mind, you will never be able to monitor any experiment objectively. Now the question is, can the mind create something which is not part of the universe? Color is part of the universe, existing in our mind, just as any other thing! Scientists hate this because they can only measure frequencies, not the "color". But what does "exist" in our mind is? Point to me in your brain at where the color red is! Don't point at neuron activities, point to where the color exist.

Extend this thought further. Then natural questions arise: How do you know the weather is not "alive". How do you know that, just as there is matter, there is consciousness? Or perhaps, consciousness is just a process, such as the fusion. But in that case, how does the universe "knows" to apply the laws of physics at every point? What is that constant everywhere which has in it embedded information to apply the laws?

Eventually one realizes that labels are labels only (including consciousness), and science is only a tool and only a model of the truth (not the truth itself). One also realizes that there is a difference between the ego "the sense of self" and knowing about the presence of it. We are lucky to know about the presence (or are we?) Listen to a music. Where in your head is the sound?

The human brain is only an artifact of the evolution of the universe. It would be interesting if we can really understand the reality itself. What would that make of the Kolmogorov complexity of reality!?

I have a definitive answer to the surgeon / cells problem.
It's very simple, actually.
Unless you are both biologically identical in factors like organ types, syndromes, illnesses / mental illnesses, blood types, body types, sizes, strength etc. then the body will not recognize the cells to be it's own and will reject them. It is almost like an organ transplant except there are so many more complications, and so it would be near impossible to recreate this.
But lets say, hypothetically, that the two are compatible. at what point would you become the other person?
Well, it would really depend where you start, as if you start from the core of who you are - the brain- then as soon as the brain and nervous system is replaced then you would theoretically be in the other persons body, but then you would still be - well, you.
No matter which way you do it, you would always not be the other person, because there would always be at least 1 cell in the way stopping you from being that person. And as soon as you get rid of that, then you are exactly the same person as before, but in the place the other person started.
So, unless somebody managed to prove me wrong by inventing a way or order of replacing cells that would make it work, my definitive answer is that it is impossible - and that's the answer simplified.
Maybe you could invent a way of perfectly merging and incubating gametes and then transferring yourself into the offspring - provided it is identical to a perfect mix of you both, then it might work. Well, for only until the being multiplies a single cell. Because errors will be made, and even if it's just a single quark off, or it doesn't experience the exact same thing as both participants, then it is a different, individual person.
Thanks for actually reading all of this, by the way.

Here is my philosophy on this subject:

I think what will happen is what happens when single cell organism undergo mitosis; the old cell cease to exists the moment two new cells are 'born' out of the old one.

From our perspective; the human brain has no centre point where the consciousness lies. It's the total sum of neuroconnections that makes up for it. That's why we can loose some parts of our brain and still function and still be 'us.' Our illusion of thinking that there must be a conscious centre point what cannot be split into two is what turns this subject into a paradox with similarities to Theseus' ship.

So what now predictably will happen when you put one half of a brain in one skull and the other half in another skull is that conscious number 1 makes place for conscious number 2 and conscious number 3 while conscious number 1 ceases to exist.
Why that is?
Because when a creature dies its neuroconnections no longer make mutual connections, and ending the relationship is ending the conscious awareness. When a brain got split the total sum of neuroconnections that once made up one consciousness is no longer there, only the tissue is still alive; we now can say that BOTH tissues are still alive.

The error is in equating consciousness as being the same or residing in the material brain. I think consciousness is a result of all things in the Universe, and not just a brain.

For example, consciousness arises because it has a proper medium - including but not limited to:
a nervous system,
a brain,
a body,
the correlating sense organs that can give rise to correlating types of consciousnesses - ie: eye, ear, olfactory, touch, taste consciouness and so on.
Furthermore, those things are still not enough to give rise to those types of consciousnesses, but in addition to all those things, there must also exist the objects of those correlating sense organs - objects (the universe itself) to see, hear, taste, touch and so on..
And finally, there must be one last thing which will complete the process of arising consiousness:
all the forementioned elements must interact in a relevant way, that is to say, there must be CONTACT between the sense organs and the correlating objects of those organs in order for feeings to arise, then perception, then mental awareness, then bias and differentiation, ending in thought of or about something.

these elements, and/or events can occur in sequence or out of sequence to some degree. But without all of them, no complete consciousness could arise, and without some or particular elements, no corresponding type of consciousness could arise - ie: without objects that come into contact with the body, no touch perception, awareness and therefore no consciousness of touch could arise. The same goes for the other elements and sense organs.

If you disagree, then consider that if consciousness were merely the same as or merely resided in the brain...or caused by the brain alone, then we would see evidence of consciousness in morgues across the world. Alas, there is no such thing. Or we find consciousness and awareness inside the womb in fetuses with complete brains.

The computer would, in effect become a duplicate of my consciousness, but not a continuation of me.

Artificial intelligence (AI, also machine intelligence, MI) is intelligence displayed by machines, in contrast with the natural intelligence (NI) displayed by humans and other animals. In computer science AI research is defined as the study of "intelligent agents": any device that perceives its environment and takes actions that maximize its chance of success at some goal.[1]Colloquially, the term "artificial intelligence" is applied when a machine mimics "cognitive" functions that humans associate with other human minds, such as "learning" and "problem solving".[2] See glossary of artificial intelligence.

The scope of AI is disputed: as machines become increasingly capable, tasks considered as requiring "intelligence" are often removed from the definition, a phenomenon known as the AI effect, leading to the quip "AI is whatever hasn't been done yet."[3] For instance, optical character recognition is frequently excluded from "artificial intelligence", having become a routine technology.[4] Capabilities generally classified as AI as of 2017 include successfully understanding human speech,[5]competing at a high level in strategic gamesystems (such as chess and Go[6]), autonomous cars, intelligent routing in content delivery networks, military simulations, and interpreting complex data, including images and videos.

Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and in the years since has experienced several waves of optimism,[7][8] followed by disappointment and the loss of funding (known as an "AI winter"),[9][10] followed by new approaches, success and renewed funding.[citation needed]For most of its history, AI research has been divided into subfields that often fail to communicate with each other.[11]

The traditional problems (or goals) of AI research include reasoning, knowledge, planning, learning, natural language processing, perception and the ability to move and manipulate objects.[12] General intelligence is among the field's long-term goals.[13] Approaches include statistical methods, computational intelligence, and traditional symbolic AI. Many tools are used in AI, including versions of search and mathematical optimization, neural networksand methods based on statistics, probability and economics. The AI field draws upon computer science, mathematics, psychology, linguistics, philosophy, neuroscience, artificial psychology and many others.

The field was founded on the claim that human intelligence "can be so precisely described that a machine can be made to simulate it".[14] This raises philosophical arguments about the nature of the mind and the ethics of creating artificial beings endowed with human-like intelligence, issues which have been explored by myth, fiction and philosophy since antiquity.[15] Some people also consider AI a danger to humanity if it progresses unabatedly.[16] Others believe that it is primarily a risk to employment: a frequently cited paper by Michael Osborne and Carl Benedikt Frey found that almost half of U.S. jobs are at risk to automation due to AI.[17]

In the twenty-first century, AI techniques have experienced a resurgence following concurrent advances in computer power, large amounts of data, and theoretical understanding; and AI techniques have become an essential part of the technology industry, helping to solve many challenging problems in computer science.[18]

Consciousness is a meta-process of the brain. What do you do when you're learning? You have to consciously focus on something. Learning is the result of the brain focussing on itself. (Awareness of self)
And for the thought experiments like 'the swamp man' Buddhism has some answers (in particular the concepts of non-self (anatta) and emptiness (sunyata). You can research this yourself but the shortest version I can give is this: we humans think in 'solid' concepts, but the real world doesn't work like that. For example, a book gets created and is destroyed, the point when is a bit blurry but most people would agree that that book existed. It didn't though, the arrangement of molecules that we call a book and we instantly tie the concept 'book' to did exist but that energy never dissapeared, it only changed form. It's the same with the concept 'I'. You have the (from an evolutionary standpoint very logical) sense of continuity because you have the same memories, the same name and roughly the same form, but your awareness only exists now (in the present). For the question 'which person are you in the future if this or that thought experiment happens' are simply nonsensical questions because in whatever case it's a different person.

Imagine at our purest, we're quite simply energy. Energy can not be destroyed, its state of being only changed or contained. In the beginning of our "life", we are not really.. "conscious"? Or if we are, we do not seem to be sustaining formidable "thought" or "memory" - yet we do, because it's how we learn to walk and talk.. even before we can remember.

Eventually comes a point we begin to comprehend ourselves as "alive". I imagine before then, our subconscious picked up and established these intuitions we express as first nature, like language and balance. But sure, we can do all these things with our body.. but what happens when our body stops working, because of disease (like aging) or something else? Our memory is not immutable, even now we forget things about ourselves and our past all the time; often something simple and mundane .. yet we can remember things in vivid detail like it was yesterday whether in a thought or a dream..

speaking of dreams, have you ever had a dream so real you honestly couldn't tell if it was a memory or a dream? Or a dream so absurd, during dream state everything seems fine and dandy.. but when you're awake you think to yourself "how did I think I was awake?". Imagine life, as a dream.. we just don't know we're not "awake". Imagine how futile and unreal it may seem to a higher state of consciousness.. if there is one.

In short, memory is fragile.. We sleep, but we can still sustain a low level of consciousness while we sleep expressively as a "dream". Even then, are we still "conscious", however we don't have anything to sensationalize "reality".. so our brain escapes to the next best thing: dreams! Even when we're not dreaming, are we just not remembering the "nothingness" that is sleep at its purest or are we basically "dead"? If so, what wakes "us" during this state of nothingness?

A million years ago, long before "us", were we essentially "sleeping"? We just didn't have a brain filled with the juicy concept of "memory" to let us dream or the sensations necessary to comprehend "life". Even then, how in the beginning at our birth did WE come to obtain such a rich combination of cells necessary to support "us"? What is memory, what is time, what is then, what is now?

The Swampman thing, unsurprisingly, reminds me of the transporters in Star Trek. I've always maintained that I would not want to use them, because although the person that pops out at the other end has the identical arrangement of molecules as me, remembers stepping onto the transporter pad, saying "energise" etc., technically, it is not me. I will have been annihilated, and the Neil that emerges will literally just have been brought into existence. No amount of research during the development of the technology could prove that the consciousness that comes out the other end is the one that went in, even though it is identical, and claims to be fine. Philosophical arguments abound ("What are 'you' anyway, other than an arrangement of molecules and a so-called 'mind' emergent from those that make up a central nervous system?"), but they'd have to be incredibly convincing to get me to believe that 'I' would be looking out of the eyes at the other end.

5:30 Of course - it will still be you. It's called Molecular Transporter Dilemma in Metaphysics. There is not a single logical reason why that still wouldn't be you. It may seem weird and unbelievable (which is normal due to the very nature of the illusion of what consciousness is - an imaginary controlling centre that lives in the brain called "self") - but in the end, - consciousness is the product of complex matter, - an interaction of different cell colonies of the brain, so if you are destroyed and then recreated atom by atom - it would ultimately still be you. In fact something similar happens every night - there is a period of deep sleep lasting around an hour in which there is no awareness and no consciousness. The parts responsible for them are not functioning. Yet you wake up and don't find it weird that you are still you. There is also a procedure called standstill surgery in which the brain is completely deprived of blood and oxygen and you are dead for all intents and purposes. But once the blood is pumped back and temperature is raised - the person is revived and still experiences illusion of continuity. Thus it would not be different if you could be annihilated and then recreated technologically. The real dilemma is whether or not a molecular transporter could actually be built.

Actually, the first place to start studying consciousness is psycholinguistics, since initial language instruction is the necessary requirement for development of consciousness. It is essentially spoken into being which makes strange misnomers like "my brain" and "my body" easier to understand. In a sense it's what Daniel Dennett refers to as "The clothes that have no emperor", with the unified "self" simply being an illusion created by interaction  between Wernike/Broca areas, Frontal lobe and other parts of the brain.

Consciousness is the connection between all of the 100 billion neurons in our brain and their reaction to stimulus as a unit through our body's senses. Consciousness is NOT a separate experience, it IS the relationship between the neurons in your brain. When any amount of those neurons are damaged or manipulated with chemical substances, our state of consciousness has the potential to change. This is why you can't exactly locate where consciousness resides in the brain and why it's still possible for the brain to adapt after a hemispherectomy. It's also the reason why people are so different in their thinking and behavior, because your neuron's reaction to stimulus (your consciousness) is exclusive to your own brain.

Well we know that our basic conscienceness evolved in self defence. To find and evade basically. Navigate to put it simpler. Imagine you were completely senseless apart from smell from birth. You wouldn't really be able to say you're conscious would you? When we experience things we store it into memory. The ability to learn  is probably a natural defense mechanism and when we're not behaving or doing something out of core instinctive reasons like fear, anxiety or hunger; and we're safe our natural anti virus switches into idle mode to keep alive. And that's what I think our conscienceness really is! Purely the constant running stream of electricity in our brain. Moving around but all still connected. The fact the brain needs to stay alive kind of backs up this idle theory. I mean, if the conscienceness was designed to protect us, what did mother nature think we would think of once we had protected ourselves? These seeming paradoxes arise because we assume that there is such a thing that makes "you" you.
Ego, the sense of self is just that, a sensation. It's an illusion. The thing that "you" feel as being you doesn't really exist.
Expierence can exist without consciousness. Consciousness is just another expierence in the same way that you expierence temperature and pain and sight. You're not always aware of it, but if you focus your attention, you can get fooled that this expierence is a real physical thing and isn't just a series of nerve implies being fired to create sensation.

I absolutely disagree that in any useful sense,  you are experiencing consciousness.  I would argue that what you are in fact interpreting as consciousness are rather crude biochemical responses to environmental cues.   Those experiences  which you are describing in this presentation as consciousness are the product of circular reasoning "I think therefore I am and I am because" without defining thought.   This is one of the greatest and most tragic errors within the study of psychology.  The consequences of poor definitions of notions such as mind, sentience, intelligence and consciousness is that the unit of measurement is always and without exception, human experience.  For this reason, no understanding of artificial intelligence will ever emerge using such a limiting  frame of reference.

What about the transporter problem?  You are taken apart, atom by atom, in your starship, and those atoms are "beamed" to the surface of an alien world and reassembled into you.  Are you still you?  Being disassembled into atoms would seem to destroy you -- it kills you and then creates an exact duplicate, with all of your memories intact.  The copy of you thinks, "Hey, it worked!  I was on the starship, and now I'm on this planet!"  The original you, however, died in the disassembly and has no more consciousness.  By all criteria the copy is, exactly, you.  Does this mean that Captain Kirk is a copy of a copy of a copy, etc?  How would we ever know?

I believe that consciousness is a mapped focus system from our brain. I think it evolved and continues to evolve. Exactly "what it is" can't be explained at this point because we only have the tech to measure things a few different ways. But once we uncover how to measure these other energy's, were going to open up a door with ALL kinds of questions that will be able to be answered like consciousness, ghosts, if a spirit exists, death, life.

But I think that consciousness is like the analogy of a revolver. Think about it, theirs the round chamber, (our head) inside are the bullets (our neurons), and the long nozzle (our consciousness) that direct the bullets on a specific focused path. Yea the bullets are just as powerful without a nozzle, but shoot the gun without a nozzle on it , and what you get is random, uncontrolled and dangerous.

With the ability to focus, observe, and predict behavior, it appears to be the PERFECT mapping system for survival through evolution. The fact that we can consciously focus the brain at something when we want, is the perception of what we call free-will.
