At least as far as we understand brain function, the left hemisphere is more objective, more mechanically and mathematically oriented. The right hemisphere on the other hand is more creative and artistically oriented. Both of these are important to any endeavor.
So if you hemisphered an expert calligrapher, we can call them Jean, the left brained Jean would hold the mechanical and technical aspects of handwriting. As opposed to he right brained Jean, who would hold the artistic nature and flourish that makes their calligraphy unique.
Calligraphy would of course be only one aspect of Jean's existence. However all but the most mundane of mechanical tasks require some creativity to execute. While most all artistic endeavors require some technical prowess. As a result despite both Jeans possessing the same experiences and raw knowledge, neither would be the same Jean, neither would have the same approach to life and living. Jean would cease to exist. That is the point of view I came up with using my left and right brains. Both of them by the way really enjoy Vsauce, and the odd mishmash of science, philosophy and art.

What do you guys think about the idea that water is a kind of disembodied awareness? Our brains are mostly water, and all our means of perception are based on water (the eyes are mostly water too, hearing and our sense of balance need water to work, your nerve endings don't work as efficiently when you're dehydrated, etc). Anyways it's just interesting to think about this question, what is consciousness? I don't think that you are a 'thing' essentially, an entity, I think that you are a function of something, i.e. the physical brain. But it feels like a 'thing' because you think you can perceive stillness. In reality, nothing is still. Atoms are always in motion. The earth is in motion, the universe is expanding, etc. Your eyes don't even work if they are perfectly still, if your eyes were perfectly still you wouldn't be able to see anything. Light only appears to be still relative to where your eyes are, but there really isn't anything that isn't moving.

Also this does not make consciousness less real, because motion is a fundamental aspect of existence. But I think consciousness is more of a function or a process than a 'thing' or a substance.

The Matrix, I liked that movie but it's not necessarily based on reality.

It would be like a network of nerve endings feeling their way around. This super consciousness only exists when all it's parts are networked, but if all humans were then disconnected this single consciousness would vanish. The consciousness wouldn't see itself as any single human, and so would see each human as more like an arm or a foot. Effectively it would be a brain. Do you see this is how it is with our own body? We only exist because of this network that is the brain along with our sense organs that are equally important. The brain "grew" and formed gradually, and as it did so our "self" also arose gradually. When we die this "network" is disconnected and so our consciousness vanishes, but all of what made us up would still be there immediately afterwards. You aren't one, you are many. You only feel like there's something to lose with death because you have a memory.

The brain of all mammals is much more complex than any computer. It is also much more efficient. Our brain consume approximately 30 Watts of energy. Every second, the visual system perform about 10 search operation. If we look at a picture of somebody, or a building or anything else, our brain can compare it to all image ever seen in our entire life.

There is no computer able to compare in a single cycle an array of data (like the X/Y array of data sent from the retina to the visual system) to the entire database on every partition of each hard drive.

Similarly, the auditive memory is scanned in parallel given any small sample of sound. For example, if I switch channel on the radio and ear any music played at any position, I can recognize the song in less than 1/2 second, after hearing just two of three consecutive note.

Sometime, when we kept forgetting some apparently simple fact such as a math formula, we are tempted to have doubt about what we can learn. However, our memory is specialized to learn some type of information which would overwhelm any computer.

It is tempting to believe that what make us conscious is located somewhere outside our body. But the reality is simpler. Everything that we think and feel is located in the brain. These 100 billion neuron are there for good reason. There is not a single one which would not be useful. The common saying "we use only 10% of our brain" is a myth. Neuron, similar to muscle, would undergo atrophy if they were not exercised.

VSauce is normally good at explaining things that are not understood by most people. It is not helpful to say "science may never understand how consciousness works". First of all, science is not made of alien from other planet. Science is alive when people care to learn something and collect information from different source. For the lucky one who get paid in the name of science, they investigate a very narrow subject in a laboratory. They repeat thousand of time some tests to collect statistical data.

For the unlucky who are not paid for learning science, we have to perform similar work anyway. Since we are born without any knowledge, each human has to repeat the same steps to learn anything. Science will understand how the brain works if enough people invest their energy to understand it.

When we die, all the information accumulated in these 100 billions neuron is lost. When the hearth stops, this mass of fatty jello stop consuming the usual 30 watts of energy, the synapse collapse progressively. After 3 minutes without blood supply, the percentage of neuron damaged exceed a given threshold. Being resuscitated past that point makes the person absent from that body.

There is a neuroscientist who experienced a stroke on the left side of her brain. She gave an excellent interview on NPR. She described how the surviving side was not really "her". This side of the brain which does not speak and react instinctively was making her behave in a way that made her not feel herself.

Obviously, the left side didn't not get completely destroyed. After more than 6 months of re-learning to talk, learning to tie shoes, hold a form and spoon, etc, she gradually recovered. Because she knew already how the brain work, she could describe in detail what happened when loosing one side. She knew that she was having a stroke and careful memorized every symptoms and effect during the few hours where the destruction was occurring.

Fun subject. Leads to some 'intellectual cul-de-sacs', lol. Despite thinking about some of the thornier areas of this for quite some time, I've been unable to fully resolve them. Philosophical zombie, yeah its a fun one.
 Another one that gets me is the one about making a perfect copy of yourself, including your memories. Would there still then be an original you? If we destroyed the 'supposed original', no one would know, or care, that the new was not still the old. No one would be able to tell in any way, either, even if they looked carefully, even scientifically. Not if it was perfect copy. So is this wild hypothetical scenario, there could 'other you's'.
The really sticky part for me has something to do with a concept I can't even fully determine to have any actual relevance to anything. So it's a quirk of mine, maybe. It has to do with something I 'feel' about something I might call the 'continuity of self':
 If I am killed and instantly replace by a perfect copy, I still somehow feel like I would be dying. And I suppose I would be. But the perfect copy calls into question not only the concept of uniqueness, but also the 'continuity of self'. I would not really know I was dead or had died, because I would be dead. The copy would pick up the next instant after my death. I'm so stuck in a loop about this it's funny. We could consider my consciousness having been transferred in the copy. But it wasn't. To me, from a certain perspective, that copy is someone else. It was a perfect copy, not a transfer. But because there was no time gap for any existence of 2 distinct copies, identical but distinct, I can't tell if that is actually in any way different from an actual transfer. I feel I should maybe be able to get this, but I think maybe I can't, or it can't be solved. What happened to the old me? The question is not as simple as it may sound.

Humans are very similar cleverbot. The difference is that we have regulatory chemicals to tell us our mood based off our external stimulus. It's a survival mechanism. If you could make a robot that could analyze a sad situation, it couldn't feel "sad" because sadness isn't an opinion, it's a sensation. However, if that same robot can distinguish a sad situation and there's a vial of a "sad" chemical that's automatically released into a dish and there's a computing software in the robots "brain" that analyzes the chemical and determines it to be the "sad" chemical and reacts accordingly to that, then it would be no different than a human by concept.

@1:20 'The awareness that you have thoughts makes up consciousness.' If that means something like 'is an example of consciousness,' then alright. If it means that the self-awareness described is a necessary condition of consciousness such that a being is not conscious unless it can be aware that it has thoughts, that is almost certainly wrong.

The split brain question in the first minute of the video is flawed, as each half brain will construct its counterpart independently and since this procedure is only possible in very young children, the impact of the original self's consciousness will be negligible to the eventual selves. The other important consideration is that removing a diseased half brain is one matter but putting in a half brain is a completely different issue. Where do you get a person without a brain? Do you remove a complete brain and replace it with a half brain? Then what about the consciousness of the person whose brain is now being replaced by the half brain?

Kind of relates to restored vehicles and airplanes.  If you look to buy a vintage aircraft, for example, like an authentic WWII era aircraft restored to running condition, they'll often say something like "every part of this vehicle has been replaced or rebuilt." The Turing test is interesting. A test developed to gauge a computers ability to exhibit intelligent behaviour, it involves a judge a human subject and a machine. The judge will hold a conversation with both using a text messaging system and if he/she can not determine which answers are given by the machine then the machine passes the test.

The Chinese room is another interesting thought experiment created to contest certain ideas about artificial intelligence. Do intelligent responses indicate actual understanding?

The mind is a hall of mirrors in which each new though reflects on previous thoughts and thus fancies itself as their “thinker" - a seemingly enduring "I," “observer,” or "self" - separate from the ever-changing stream of thoughts and emotions. For all its machinations the “thinker” is just as transitory as every other thought - being itself merely a sequence of thoughts about thoughts about thoughts ad infinitum.

This duplicity ostensibly allows the mind to distance itself from its shadowy, more unpalatable, impulses – its envy, its greed, its fears, its animosities - by fabricating a make-believe "I" separate from "them." It seeks to create a chasm which hides this darker side from itself but which also prevents the light of awareness from reaching and illuminating it. "I" do not have "those" reprehensible qualities or, "I" am burdened and distressed by "those" feelings. The "I" can then make half-hearted efforts to change "those" unwelcome characteristics without fundamentally acknowledging "them" as itself. "They" are not me; "they" are "happening" to me. It is a devilish ruse meant to hamper the disconcerting recognition that the "I" is, in fact, "those" negative attributes. The mind, in effect, seeks to bury its head in the sand and pretend it is "something" other than "those" unacceptable parts of itself.

So long as that subterfuge persists - an "observer" or "experiencer" separate from its "experience" - there is little possibility of integrating and resolving the disowned impulses. The "experiencer," being a fiction, is impotent and has negligible effect on "its" experience. Only a clear choiceless awareness of the stream of experience, unclouded by the chatter of an imaginary "self" or "thinker," can expedite that integration. In that benevolent silence the mind can begin to spontaneously perceive the way out of its maze of "self"-imposed contradictions .

The undivided, “self-less,” mind bestows coherence and lucidity on all its encounters. It is the only truly sane mind amongst all. The divided mind, try as it may not to do so, exacerbates the pandemonium, disorder, and confusion in the world via its dissonant vacillation between a nonexistent "thinker" and "its" thoughts.

He asks "When would I become you and you become me if we switched bodies cell by cell?", but this is a loaded question which relies on the philosophy of naturalism which says that all that exists is the natural. He never addresses the possibility that we can be more than just our cells. Maybe the answer is that the bodies would switch completely and the mind or conscience would not. I am not claiming one philosophy is right while another is wrong, for no one can ever know, but I am saying to be careful to be aware of your own philosophical beliefs. Philosophy is unfortunately forever tied to science.

I am not at all convinced that I am not just a more sophisticated Cleverbot. I am perhaps exactly the same thing as Cleverbot, but I respond to more than one type of input, and addons within my program which exist primarily for one function are able to cross reference information from other functions. This makes the program self-referential, which is where the illusion of self arises, because the program cannot reference itself without reifying itself (identifying itself as a Thing that exists with certain boundaries and qualities that may or may not be objectively true [like the inconsistency of our atomic makeup, even though we say we have the same body throughout our lives]). That's why we are becoming increasingly cybernetic, creating computerized prosthetics that can replace arms and electronic retinas that can feed information to or receive instructions from our brains. What makes most sense to me is that consciousness is a field, a singularity. When you go deeper into reality, things are less physical and more energetic. Eventually you get to where modern science has mostly agreed on, the Grand Unified Field. GUF theory theorizes that everything that is a thing, everything that happens, the genesis of every single event and creation in this universe comes from that field. From the big bang, to your own thoughts, everything ultimately emerges from there. Now what's easy for me to extrapolate from that theory is that all matter, as we know isn't as physical as we think, is based in "consciousness," which is still beyond our grasps, and what we call "consciousness" is what our brains do, which is instead of being a plant or a rock and expanding from the GUF to something physical and motionless, a nervous system is able to focus back down into the GUF and/or operate closer to that level, the extent varying between animals and people and some other things, and what we call consciousness, are the filters our brains create to transmit and use some of the creative elements of the one signal/energy that has always been under everything, never changing since the formation of the universe.

To answer the original question of the video in my understanding.

Consciousness is the point of awareness that is aware of itself (Source/God/etc).....the significant thing about it, is that there is only 1 of it and although all of us think we are individuals, we are actually all extensions of the 1 consciousness - it lives and experiences through us.

This consciousness is omnipresent, and combined with water (which somehow is able to house), it gives life to otherwise dead matter. Humans, animals, plants and all other living things contain this consciousness but, this consciousness looks through the filter of each individual's experience, giving it a personality (based on its experience) and Ego (individuality). There are lots of New Age sayings that talk about how we've forgotten what we are (the 1 consciousness) and now think that we are just the individual, separate from everything else(Ego), and hence we act that way.

Obviously, there is no proof of this, its just a belief.

We can look at the brain, at every part of it, every cell, and all we find is very complex structures; systems created by nerve-cells which relay biochemical and electrical impulses. It is incredibly complex, beyond imagination, but it is nothing more than that: a cell-structure with a system. Nothing magical, no elements or objects we only see inside our brain and nowhere else in the universe. 
It is this complexity, and only this, that creates the illusion of conciousness. Think about it: is an ape concious? A rabit? a worm? an ant? a jelly-fish? It is not black and white; conciousness is a degree of complexity which allows us to visualize ourselves in different situations, to evaluate our options. This has a huge evolutionary advantage.

We cannot even begin to comprehend death as it is. To cease, to just stop everything in our own heads.

It's not like sleep because we are no longer aware of time, nor do we have the capacity to process information, which is why it's physically impossible for our minds to comprehend it. It's like trying to draw a 4 dimensional object, it just doesn't make sense to our brains.

When your heart stops, you fall unconscious and you no doubt, sit in your own head for a little bit, thinking to yourself for your last moments. Until slowly parts of your brain begin dying, begin stopping. You start to unlearn everything. First you forget minor details, then major events, then people, then eventually your own name. Your brain can no longer process mathematical equations or understand physics or visualize an image in your own mind. Everything goes dark and just before you stop, you're perception of time slows to a crawl and for both an eternity and in an instant: You die.

But that's just my best guess and I'd love to do more research on that question. I'd also really like to see Michael do a video on it as well, just to get his perspective on the whole thing. Maybe a request if it gets enough likes? "What does it feel like to die?"

Looking for consciousness in the physical brain is like looking for songs, movies or computer games among electronic circuit boards and memory chips in a PC. You can find the physical/mechanical parts, but not the “software” manifestations.

Present technology allows us to record regions in the brain where these codes might be stored, regions where these codes might be computed according to naturally formed algorithms, and regions that perform subsequent computations as a response to upstream computational results. We are not yet able to extract the codes, or their operational algorithms. We can only detect the brain regions that are being activated in the computational process.

Consciousness, the software, cannot be observed scientifically this way.

Consciousness is a set of software programs created by nature in our brain, assumingly through evolution. The working logic and functionalities of this software set also undergoes evolutionary development. The codes, as electro/chemical signals stored in the brain, constantly rewire themselves to produce version 2.0, 3.0, or 3.1, as response to situational stimulations.

Imagine a device that gives us not only sensations of visuals (like a computer screen), sound (like a pair of speakers), touch (like in a 4-D theatre), etc. Imagine the functional capabilities of that device being transformed from analogue physical/mechanical operations into computational algorithms that manifests themselves through electro/chemical actions inside the brain.

Imagine all our sensory faculties also being transformed into computational algorithms, sensing (like reading off a computer screen) the output of the device (now a set of computational algorithms) above. A key part of our consciousness is the set of sensory faculty computational algorithms, sort of like a software “inner eye”.

It views our inner movie. It is aware of the movie show fed by other parts of our brain through electro/chemical signals. It has algorithms that can decipher the signals and perceive them as human experience. It also has algorithms that help to make decisions and send command signals to various parts of human body.

Like physical parts in a PC, physical parts in the brain provide the environment for these electro/chemical activities to take place. We cannot find the software manifestations there, although we might be able to find locations where the codes of the software are being electro/chemically stored. This seems to be like a RAM disk, if you turn off the electric current supply, the codes could be lost. Death could then be an experience of these life-long computations shutting down.

Well, since a lot of you peeps seem to have the answers to the universe, tell me:

If 'Consciousness' is as physically bound by our bodies as much as life or what's considered the "real", then what happens after death? We don't seem to 'go' anywhere, right? We just die? Or do we lack the ability to comprehend such a state whilst being alive? Furthermore, what of dreams? Ideas? Thought? Are we literally just robots being piloted by a brain? I am a 10 lb brain piloting a 150 lb slab of meat.

Hm.. I'm imagining our physical body operating kind of like car.

Where in order to operate it, we must continually perform necessary maintenance. 

Energy?... Fill the tank with gasoline = fill our belly with food.

Lubrication?... Replenish oil in the car = replenish water in our body.

All the other fluids/maintenance the car needs, as well as some less vital maintenance like wishy washy fluid, is maybe like maintaining proper nutrition with sufficient levels of minerals and vitamins and proteins in our bodies.

Furthermore, the car is not capable of waking up and running completely by itself,

BUT when we embody the vehicle and turn the power on, it is then able to utilize the resources that we provide to run on it's own... at least until the resources provided are exhausted or main components fail, et cetera.

And even though the car/our body will continue operating it's own system to stay alive/running, for movement to take place there must be a driver.

I feel like this is where consciousness comes in. To me it seems like the seemingly "separate" functioning of our vehicle and our consciousness exists this way so all of the necessary body system processes can run almost machine like without conscious thought or input.
Resulting in our ability to focus our thought on other stuff like paying attention to where we are going or deciding what we want to experience while interconnected with an impressive body, or maybe pondering different ideas about our existence.

I also feel like the "separation"  is why we are even able to be conscious and have a human experience. The machine and soul share a connection and because of that connection, that bond, both the body and soul have the opportunity to experience self consciousness or awareness.

Otherwise I feel like we experience something much like when we are asleep and not lucid dreaming. Nothingness. Not even being aware of the incredible amount of nothingness. If there can even be an amount of nothingness?

Consciousness is a property of the muscular system. 
Our muscular system can unify isometrically into a single muscle, which in Hinduism is called Purusha. 
The point towards which our muscular system contracts acts as a cursor and can moved in the mid line between our feet and head. By default it would be at the level of our navel. This cursor is what we call 'I'. 
Lower this cursor lesser would be our consciousness and lesser would be our consumption of energy. Thus, our consciousness is least during sleep and highest during a battle for survival. Thus, consciousness is a mechanism that optimizes energy expenditure. 
By default it is 50% under our control. We can control consciousness completely or make it fully automatic. 
When the mechanism of consciousness is fully automatic, we get an illusion that it is brain that is controlling it. However, we can have manual control over the entire range of consciousness. Since we can neither feel nor control our brain, it is obvious that it is the muscular system that is the commander of the body and not the brain. In this case the brain becomes irrelevant.

Personally I believe that consciousness is a metaphysical product that occurs as a result of any self regulatory, sufficiently complex physical system, that sustains itself and reacts to enviromental changes. Brains are the prime example of this, consciousnes created by a system of electric charges and transport of biochemical molecules.

However you can transfer the concept to systems such as trees or forrests, where all trees share the same root system, extendig over squaremiles. It can be applied to entire ecosystems, with every component taking the role of a neuron or transmitter reacting and acting on other components of the system.

If you look at the dynamics of large groups of people, it is more than just the sum of the intentions and actions of every individual of that group, since they continously influence each other at all times no single person can ever be in control of all "variables", so the complex system can mathematically only be described as an enormous differential equation, where all variables are dependent of each other. Changing one leads to change in those that are dependent on it, and then more changes in all those variables that are dependent on the ones that were changed by the very first variation.This is exactly the type of mathematic modell that scientists use to describe the brain, where all these dependencies are closed in on each other in such a way that they create a stable system, balancing each other out.

If you look at the universe on the largest possible scale, you find filaments of galaxy clusters arranged in what looks exactly like a neuronal network. Within this network matter and energy are being transported and interact with each other according to the laws of physics (again the sum of forces of interaction between all matter and energy can only be described through differential equations). The Universe might just be one massiv consciousness with levels of subcionsciousnesses through physical networks spread over the wide spectrum of size magnitudes.
We might be in some way special because our consciousness is created by a physical system (brain) on a size magnitude that is dead center in the scale between the largest (whole universe) and the smallest (quarks), perhaps the goldylock zone of consciousness, but then again that might just be anthropocentric ignorance.

At the physics department of my university (Goethe University in Frankfurt/Germany) we have a brilliant theoretical physics professor, Prof. Dr. Claudius Gros, who is a pioneer in the research of Complex Systems. Also I have heard the introductionary lecture "Brain Dynamics" by the Neuroscientist Dr. Thomas Burwick.
All in all I hope that I can learn more about this subject in the future and maybe find evidence for my theory.

"Maxwell's demon told us that knowledge inolves the world. That information is a notion which is based on thermodynamics, and understanding of heat and steam engines. I have always had a theory thats in a sense indirectly related. Explained in my way, If i were to clone my self, that clone would not be me, that clone would only be me for the first few seconds or minutes of their life, and from that point on, despite having my thought patterns and the way I feel about things, may or may not differentiate from me, if the clone does find different views from me, despite being able to agree with me or debate with me on stuff we'd already know or have wondered, they would split off into their own personality, that clone looks like me, has my blood and dna, my memories, knowledge, wisdom ect, but they from the start develop their own consciousness, while its speculated that a clone would be a perfect copy, I believe that a clone even if they did everything the same, thought the same, said the same things, from that point forward, or even if not, would develop their own consciousness, because i know at the end of the day, he doesnt see through my eyes, but hes obviously a person with his own personality albeit however identical to mine.

If you could take a grown man, split his brain into 2 different bodies, I feel that in a sense it would be no different than having a clone, although the bodies would be different, that 2nd individual would develop differently than I would and vice versa. in a sense, all it would take is one differentiated thought or opinion or lack of agreement to prove such theory, especially when and where you place both personas into different environments of the same situation without contact, and then try to gather both sides of the story, yes I feel that even clones would essentially be people.

But then what IF i died, and I was cloned back to life, what I want to know then is will that be me, or will that be the new me who takes over from there on, the answer I'd give is that isn't me, thats the new Flynn while he may think like me, have my memories, thoughts ect, that isn't the original Flynn, because at some point, he will do something differently than what I would have done in the first place based of all available information being processed in that brain, even if both of us were in 100% identical situations. What bugs me about this whole theory is the power and freedom of individual thought and decision, but I know even if i died and then was cloned, I would not be looking through that second set of eyes, I would technically still be dead. 

I could have an army of clones of me, but I'd still watch my own back because the power of individual freedom and thought and the feelings that go with it, will cause indifference between all of us, because that's the power we were given, individuality, maybe at some point my own clone would say I don't want to be like you because im just a copy, and boom, they've immediately developed their own consciousness, part of that is because if I had my own family, and that clone cant have the same, who are they then? someone that isn't me

Consciousness is an abstract model in a person's neocortex that emerges as a response to the apparent similarity between the behaviors of both other people and the person the brain itself controls. Just because the brain creates a model of something that seems consistent doesn't mean that it should correspond to a physical entity. Once the consistency fails (perhaps due to brain injury), the model may be violated and the concept of consciousness becomes vague.

The problem with someone trying to posit that consciousness/mind is mere by-product functioning of brain is that mathematics, reason and logic would also be results of this mere by-product functioning of brain from “Mind”. If morality, self awareness and choice (freewill) are also mere products of mind it would then seem to be just picking and choosing to trust logic over self-awareness or mathematics over morality and in the end becomes some form of “begging the question”. The only real questions left are, "is consciousness trustworthy to know reality and if so, is it also a necessary part of reality itself?" We have in fact only consciousness to rationalize consciousness. All rational inferences, testing models against experienced reality, conceptualizing models, logic and probability theories arise from consciousness/mind and all of these listed don't and can't exist without consciousness. “Consciousness” or the “Mind” accounts for all reasoning with nothing left outside of this self-awareness that is able to encounter or reason reality otherwise.

Consciousness is the substrate of any possible claim to knowledge and thus the starting and ending point to posit a reality or any truth. Why would one limit themselves to posit empiricism as true, which is also a product/idea of mind but this world-view denies one's self, the objective reasoner, as no more than mere biochemical illusory as the result of it's assertions. Empiricism states that knowledge must be restricted to those objects which can be perceived by our senses. At the same time empiricism requires non-empirical foundational presuppositions and these presuppositions are not material themselves, they are metaphysical. Science must assume mathematics, logic and human reason trustworthy and that the Universe is rational and in line with a rational human consciousness/mind because these are not physical objects which can be perceived by any of our five senses. Mathematics, logic and reason originate and reside in the metaphysical consciousness, the mind. These metaphysical conceptual constructs can not be tested/falsified outside of themselves empirically. Empiricism alone is self-refuting layer upon layer. The theory that all knowledge is limited to what can be empirically known is itself, incapable of being known or demonstrated empirically. When adding the fact that empiricism can not answer for any trustworthy substrate for knowledge that is solely metaphysical (one's self, the objective reasoner); and the fact that the only substrate for claimed knowledge is “one's self, the objective reasoner”, shows empiricism as fallacious at it's core claim of being the only methodology for knowledge. Mind/consciousness is one's self, the objective reasoner and only possible source for any claim of knowledge to/of reality. Science may inform humans of what we are but science can ever inform us of who we are; one's self, the objective reasoner to and of reality.

C.S. Lewis describes the moral issue from within conscious beings reasoning like this;

"My argument against God was that the universe seemed so cruel and unjust. But how had I got this idea of just and unjust? A man does not call a line crooked unless he has some idea of a straight line. What was I comparing this universe with when I called it unjust? If the whole show was bad and senseless from A to Z, so to speak, why did I, who was supposed to be part of the show, find myself in such violent reaction against it? A man feels wet when he falls into water, because man is not a water animal: a fish would not feel wet. Of course, I could have given up my idea of justice by saying that it was nothing but a private idea of my own. But if I did that, then my argument against God collapsed too--for the argument depended on saying that the world was really unjust, not simply that it did not happen to please my private fancies. Thus in the very act of trying to prove that God did not exist--in other words, that the whole of reality was senseless--I found I was forced to assume that one part of reality--namely my idea of justice--was full of sense. Consequently atheism turns out to be too simple. If the whole universe has no meaning, we should never have found out that it has no meaning: just as, if there were no light in the universe and therefore no creatures with eyes, we should never know it was dark. Dark would be without meaning." ~C.S. Lewis

I once smoked salvia by accident, and it blew apart my concepts of consciousness. It felt like I was a tiny sphere inside my skull, and every time I tried to move or say anything it was like bright beams of light shooting out of the sphere that were translated into movement and sounds as they left my skull. Every time I experienced something like sound or textures it was like hot water rushing at me, and then fusing together into little electrical spheres spinning around me 'explaining' to me what it is suppose to feel like. It was so freaky, I have not looked at my brain the same way since. lol Even to this day, I can 'feel' everything happening within my skull, I have 'pain displacement' which means it's hard for me to tell where pain is coming from, because if I say, step on a nail, I can feel the pain originating from inside my brain, instead of the illusion of it coming from my foot that my brain would normally want me to feel.

Reality is so weird, the human brain is no exception, what it does is so complex, and intense, and beautiful, and I never even realized it before, but now I can really feel what my brain does for me. And it makes me really wonder, if I am just something that arises from the brain's activity, in the same way I arise from the activity of countless atoms, or if there is something fundamentally different inside my brain that is really 'me'...

When the brain dies, the consciousness dies; when a computer "dies", that software "dies" too. When people get old and their brains get sick and they get Alzheimer's or whatever, their brain states change. Your consciousness changes. It's a physical process, It doesn't point anything outside.

When the stomach disappears, the functioning disappears, and so that word is not used anymore. The same concept with the brain, the mind, the consciousness of the brain, the subjective experiences that we have, and other species of animal as well : there is internal states that we call subjective but they are really functions, some people might argue that they're epiphenomena, but in any event they only happen when a physical organ is working.

Consciousness and mental states are functions, they're not things. Consciousness is not a thing, you can't go the store and buy some consciousness, you can't say "How much consciousness do you have?". You can't weigh it, you cant measure it. You can only describe it as a function, just like we describe digestion as a function of an organ, the digestive system. If you put a capital "D" on digestion, you wouldn't say "Oh! There's digestion in the cosmos!"

Genetically identical twins occur when one human zygote splits into two.

So there really is no answer as to what is consciousness.

You cannot change the physical properties of a molecule with willpower alone.

Technically yes that example is true, but not true in this situation. By just putting a single "word" in quotations does not make it a quote, the quotations are simply emphasizing that single word. In the example you showed, it is a direct quotation from a persons speech, in which case yes the punctuation goes inside the quotation marks. However when emphasizing a word with quotations the punctuation goes outside the quotations marks indicating the end of the sentence.

I'm not sure how reliable your source is, but I'm in college and we put the punctuation outside the quotes.
It also makes more sense to put it outside, since you are quoting what they said and transplanting it back into the grammar of your own sentence structure. The quote is an object inside the sentence, and thus the punctuation is outside so as to end the whole sentence.

Since the Broca's area (the speech center of the brain) is only in the left hemisphere, only the left hemisphere can vocalize thought, however the right hemisphere can indicate answers to a question by writing or pointing. Using this technique with a split-brain patient, it was found that the right hemisphere of the brain believed in a God, while the left hemisphere did not. Keep in mind this is still one person; their hemispheres just can't communicate anymore.

If you think about it, you already are sort of like two people in "one" body. If you look at split-brain patients (people who have their corpus callosum severed to prevent seizures), one half of their body can have different beliefs than the other half. In these patients, due to the inability of their two hemispheres to communicate, their brain has no way of weighing logic and reasoning (left hemisphere) against artistry and intuition (right), so the two halves can have conflicting beliefs.

What you are describing is IMAGINATION, not perception. In order to perceive color, you need some sort of "input device" like an eyeball that can perceive light. However, you talk about synesthesia. Synesthesia is automatic. Imagination is both automatic and voluntary. Synesthesia can give somebody altered perception, but it cannot alter what doesn't exist to begin with. But imagination can be used to perceive things outside of input. The whole is greater than the sum of its parts.

Science cannot even accurately define what "beauty" is, much less whether or not it even exists. Artists even have a hard time defining what it is. What makes you think that science can prove that beauty not only exists, but also prove that we are somehow capable of perceiving it?

Who says that to perceive colour you must see?
A human like her, most likely developed her sense so that she could feel these waves. Like most humans can feel the texture of an object, and its shape, she could feel the colours. If you have heard about synesthesia, or even had such an experience, it should be pretty clear that the senses are just one single thing, but with different inputs. Its like switching a cd reader for a card reader, but in the end receiving the same information.

I accept your idea in theory, but not in practice. And one reason is because of the writings of Helen Keller. A woman with no way of perceiving light or sound wrote remarkably detailed accounts of things like colors. If your theory were true, then a woman like Helen Keller would NEVER be able to develop as a human being the way she did, because the sum of her perceived wavelengths was vastly diminished.

Perhaps there are things that we can never learn through science, but science is the best tool we have for determining what is true. Simply saying that science imperfect is not proof that there is a way to improve or what such a way would be. Your insistence that the idea of an immaterial universe must be assumed seems to be based on your opinion. Also, psychology is a science that could help us explain why we find things beautiful and why we dance, so those weren't very good examples.

Mainstream science is wonderful in some ways, and in things like mathematics and physics, it can learn and grow nearly forever. Physics can explain what causes the colors of a sunset, but it cannot explain why they are beautiful. Mathematics can explain the patterns found in nature and music, but it cannot explain why those patterns make a person clap and dance. After all, science cannot prove that science itself is true. One must first believe it is true, before science can be done.

We measure the non-material all the time. Information is immaterial, and we can measure it in things called bits and bytes. Intelligence is non-material, and we measure it in something called IQ. Knowledge is non-material, and we measure it with something called Graduate Degrees. Compassion is non-material, but we can measure it just by observing people and talking with them.  Just because something is immaterial, it doesn't mean it's not real.

Simply choose to ignore reductionism and materialism. Start with the assumption that the material universe is not all that exists, and that some things are more than just the sum of their parts.  With those two assumptions in place, common sense and scientific process will take you down the right line of questions to ask.

Just like information is lost when you reduce a paper menu to a puddle of inky pulp, so too does consciousness disappear when you reduce down a human being to individual components. Both are greater than the sum of their parts. The act of looking at individual parts rather than the whole will cause something to be lost in the process. The only way to explain consciousness, without losing some in the process, is by using a top-down approach, where the mind is greater than the sum of its parts.

So when I say that reductionism and materialism cannot explain consciousness, I say so because some things CANNOT be reduced. For example, a menu at a restaurant. If you reduce the menu to its individual atoms and molecules, and study them, you will know what kind of paper was used, what kind of ink was used, and maybe even the origins of the materials involved. But once you reduce that menu to its base components, the message is lost. You cannot scientifically determine what was for dinner.

I understand what you mean, and I hope I can answer you. It's a matter of how science gathers knowledge. The way science works is by materialism and reductionism. Materialism is the assumption (with no way of knowing if it's true or not) that the observable universe is all that exists. Reductionism says that everything can be reduced to its individual components, and be understood from a bottom-up perspective. Understand the pieces, and you understand the whole.

...acting like any other particle in the universe, but with of course with far more complicated paths and reactions, which would make us seem irrational to a robot with extreme intelligence and a degree of emotion but without our biological imperatives. But I think, again, that we ultimately operate under the same principles as that robot, or a computer, or any other kind of particle in the universe. Because we ARE particles, just in a very complex combination.

Basically, we store data in our brains in a more complicated but similar way to a computer. As with all forms of matter, we always take the path of least resistance. The difference is that for animals, that includes 'internal' resistance, the resistance of the mind. Thus, we will take actions that, according to our personal philosophies, personalities and experiences, are the right actions to take, bad or not, against all odds or not: the path of least resistance....

I feel like there might not actually be that much difference (principle-wise) between how artificial intelligence operates and how our minds operate. The primary difference is that we are far, far, far, more complicated, and we also have biological impulses (feelings) that greatly affect our judgement and the way we behave but are not necessarily logical. However, we ARE matter, and so are robots. We are extremely complex chemical reactions but we operate under the same principles as all matter.

It could be argued that from one moment in time to the next you are a different person but just share the same memories and genetic disposition and thus tend to act in a consistent manner and have a sense of "self". It's a complicated issue, really, and there might not actually be a real answer to what the "self" is and that it is simply an illusion of how we experience things. But then it could be said that that is just what "self" is, so it IS simple. Weird, isn't it?

(part 1/5) There is a theory which states that consciousness is all around us, comprehensive, and that our brains receive and process only the small part of it that is relevant to ourselves. Compare this with a radio that is tuned to one certain wavelength, while obviously there is a whole spectrum of wavelengths out there. The small part that your brains absorb and the way your brains process this part determine to a large extent your identity.

(part 2/5) Some people have brains in which this feature has been developed somewhat further; these brains, to continue the radio comparison, catch multiple channels at once. There are for example cases of people who can describe their own surgery under total anesthesia, and who are even able to repeat what was said during it. There are for example people who can get images of events that have happened in the past in the place where they currently are.

(part 3/5) The theory would make these phenomena plausible. Furthermore, it is still not known what our brains are all capable of and it is doubtful whether we ever will come that far, which leaves open the possibility that the radio comparison can be correct. 
And ponder this: many religions promise heaven - perfect love and happiness - after death. Perfect happiness may be imaginable as being part of comprehensive consciousness: you would know everything, understand everyone, see everything...

(part 4/5) and from this state you would be able to love perfectly, because you already know in detail what actions and thoughts/words hurt others and what unhappy consequences from these will eventually affect yourself. After your death you have indeed no more brains that keep the major part of comprehensive consciousness away from you - so that fits into the theory as well. Of course, for this you do have to believe in life after death, but many of us do.

(part 5/5) I'm not saying that this is the truth: it is a theory. I'm not denying that this is farfetched. But remember that once an earth in the shape of a sphere was farfetched.

The Swampman Question (at around 5:30): IF it was an EXACT replication of every atom in your body in the exact same configuration, then it would be you, except in a totally different location. you'd have no memory of moving, but you'd be in a different place. 
The Surgeon Question (at around 5:50): You simply wouldn't  become him. You'd remain you, and your friend would remain himself. If all of your cells were switched, you'd have effectively transported. You'd have switched places.
